Another point, which struck me very forcibly during my visit to Sinkiang, is the desirability of our exercising a stricter control over British Indians m Chinese Turkestan. There are, I believe, only about 500 of these Indians registered as British subjects in His I/ajesty’s Consulate General at Kashgar. The present systen is that these men once registered are left to their own devices and are probably in many cases never heard of again unless and until they get into trouble with the Chinese Authorities. It would, I submit, be much better if every British Indian m Sinkiang were provided with a proper passoort, visa'ed by the local authorities for residence in the Province, and if it were compulsory for him to renew his consular registration annually. This is the system in force in the case of British subjects in the interior of China Proper, and its adoption m Sinkiang would, 1 am .sure, save much trouble and friction with the local authorities.* & i.Z. 842/36. Registration of British Indians resident in Sinkiang. - This was a fight, with, on the face of things, a satisfactory outcome, since Mr. Ch'ea was eventually pinned down to the principle of two generations, which he was evidently out to challenge. I understand from His Majesty’s Consul-General that his latest instructions from the Government of India are also not very clear on this point, but I venture to suggest that it would be most unwise for us on our side to go back on the understanding which was, I believe, reached with the Chinese Government some ten or fifteen years ago that we would claim to protect in Sinkiang as British subjects only those Indians who had themselves come, or whose fathers had come, from India. It is true that according to the Chinese Nationality Law individuals of however remote a foreign descent, in the male line, are not Chinese citizens unless they or their ancestors have been naturalized as Chinese. But one must face the realities of the situation in Chinese Turkestan and the very delicate and difficult position arising from the continued existence of British extra-territorial rights in Sinkiang, where (as in the rest of China) a British Indian subject, but not a Russian or a German, is exempt from Chinese jurisdiction, even though he was born in the Province and mingles freely with the rest of the native Turki population; whereas in the neighbouring lands of Central Asia, e.g., in Russian Turkestan, Persia, or Afghanistan, he enjoys no such immunities. I take this opportunity of submitting, the following observations on the general question of the registration and protection of Britisn Indians in Chinese Turkestan,. If a serious attempt is now to be made to arrive at an agreed list of names with the Chinese Authorities and to settle disputed cases by means of Joint Enquiries, it seems very desirable, in such disputed cases, to produce as far as may be possible official documentary proof from India of an individual or his father having been born in a specified place in India and to refrain from pressing the claims to British registration of men born in Sinkiang of whose Indian parentage there is no such documentary proof. It would also, I think, be advantageous if some system could be introduced (as in the rest of China) by which all registered British Indians in Sinkiang were provided with passports in the prescribed form and their local consular registration annually renewed thereon. If the Chinese Authorities wished to viser these passports annually for residence in the interior of Sinkiang, there would seem to be no objection to such a requirement. I am aware that owing to local conditions, and to the fact that the Khotan area is still under rebel control, it might be difficult to introduce such a system in Chinese Turkestan at present. But if and when it is possible to introduce it, the advantages would, it seems to me, be very considerable, and cases such as that of Zarif Khan (see next paragraph) could not so easily arise. mods.abstract: Short annual reports on the workings of the China (Kashgar) Order-in-Council 1920 and 1935 for the years 1929-42. The reports contain information on the civil and criminal cases tried and the numbers of British subjects and British protected persons registered during each year.The reports were sent by the Consul General, Kashgar, to the Foreign Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign and Political Department, New Delhi, from where they were forwarded to the Political Department of the India Office, London.In addition the file contains correspondence (drafts, copies, and originals) between these three offices and the Foreign Office that concerns the following matters in connection with the working of the Order-in-Council:The prohibition under the provisions of the Order-in-Council of two British Indian subjects from being within the limits of the Kashgar consular district for opium dealingThe request, in April 1931, for the authority to repeal certain regulations made under the Order-in-CouncilThe question of the correct channels to use when corresponding about such matters.Also contained in the file are the following:A copy of the China (Kashgar) Order-in-Council, 1920 (folios 114-125)Extracts from reports on Sir Eric Teichman's mission to Sinkiang to investigate the sharp increase in the number of British subjects being registered there, dated 4 December 1935 (folios 37-41).
